author: oarsoid
review: I have to start with words of praise for the game. I first bought the game half a year ago for PS4 launch and it was incredible. I finished the game, spent a good 100 hours in it and what a game that was! Truly a masterpiece. Logging into social club was awkward, but it never bothered me once after, so it was a smooth sailing.A couple of weeks back my friends convinced me that I need to join their posse in RD Online and get it on my PC. So I did, I bought the $80 edition, went through the 100GB download and wanted to start playing. I was expecting something on par with my PS4 experience. Boy was I wrong.Game requires not one, not two, but THREE launchers to be operational - Steam, Rockstar launcher and the despicable Social Club.So far I've spent 30 minutes to 1.5 hours trying to start the game DAILY. Today was it - I sat there trying and trying and trying again and spent my last hour with red dead 2. I cannot start the game whatever I do.The vicious circle starts with ACTIVATION ERROR greeting me upon loading. Looks like thisThen it basically two things - either you are not logged on into social club, or the rockstar launcher. I tried both, with multiple captchas and every time it lags for MINUTES. Why? How much time does it require to verify the login, jesus!Second thing I see then is the cloud sync conflict. Naturally RETRY doesn't do anything! You start anew waiting each time for these stupid launchers to crawl for 5-10 minutes before even attempting to launch the applicationThen I'm being reminded that after paying $80 I still don't own the game: I try relogging into launch - and it doesn't let me complaining about authentication tickets I had to reset the password to break through this one. And boy was that fun - launcher was stuck with 'expired auth token' - and outright refused to log me in with a new password. Mind you, each attempt costs you a few minutes of LAG.Then I get another one after playing good 20 hours And another one And another one this one was so horrible, I'm still shaking - basically after the password change in the rockstar launcher, the social club just refused to let me into the game. It gives no options naturally, only Quit. What they don't show you is that you can press HOME twice then sign out there, then sign in, then quit the game (because at this stage it is no longer operational regardless of that you actually DID login into the social club), and then it MAYBE works. It gave me the menu, but after trying to get Online, I got disconnected with 0x10022190 - What is the reason for it? Only god knows. Some people on reddit say it's when you have bad internet connection. My 1Gigabyte network says otherwise.But when I do login, I have roughly 2-40 minutes to play before I hit another bomb with sudden disconnection and lost progress, naturally. It's HORRIBLE. It's mind-numbingly stupid, slow and borderline painful.That being said, I know I have quite a few hours played, but I just can't anymore. It's a great game that I can't play. A few days in a row I spend more time trying to login than actually playing. It's ridiculous experiense that leaves me filled up with anger and disappointment.

author: Ossi ㋛
review: The popularity of Red Dead Redemption, being a console exclusive, was incredible. At the time, the Internet was full of fan made art and posters of the game and even some fan fiction continuations of the story. But, beside a really great DLC - named Undead Nightmare, the franchise went silent for years, though, it was never forgotten. Everything went viral in Fall 2016 when Rockstar teased the return with a new company logo, themed similarly to the colors which the franchise is known for. It turned out that a new Red Dead game was in development, which is set years prior to the popular "sequel". Knowing 2010's Red Dead Redemption, RDR2 had a lot to live up to with a limitation to the story, having in mind that many players already know the outcome. It's oddly satisfying to say that it manages to deliver a beautiful, carefully written story with a big number of memorable characters you interact with. It's set in 1899, an era where the society began to modernize and little to no space was left for the dying breed that the cowboys were. Dutch van der Linde and his gang refuse to accept the new ways of living and are in constant clash with the law. You, Arthur Morgan, are part of that gang, one of Dutch's closest people and are set on a quest to earn enough money so that the gang can leave the area and disappear once and for all.Dutch's ideals are phylosophical and often not the most unrealistic ones, but the way of going through that path has to result in constant robberies and a huge number of dead people, both innocent and guilty ones. After a disastrous robbery attempt in Blackwater, the gang has lost a lot of its members. The law is constantly chasing them and there are bounty hunters waiting around corners, ready to kill. On the run, the gang is slowly being torn apart. Arthur is a man of a slow realization of his gang's terrible deeds who, while remaining loyal, is starting to question Dutch's transformation and his way of handling situations.The camp is crucial to the game and story... Or so they want us to think. Dutch will complain about being broke no matter how much money you donate. Essentially, all the camp activities can be totally ignored, and nothing will change, really. Beside Dutch, there are some, expectedly, familiar faces in the game such as John Marston, his wife and son and a few other characters known from the original Red Dead Redemption. Essentially, it is very hard to provide any details without spoiling the end of the story, but RDR2's story is beautiful. Arthur's character transformation throughout the story is haunting and in reality, I started playing the game wanting to play as John Marston, but ended up wishing to remain as Arthur. His character arc is really amazing and he certainly is one of the best protagonists I've ever seen.One of the crucial elements of any game is its gameplay. From the wide variety of animal life to the random encounters with strange NPCs and the weird and mysterious places you may come across, RDR2 has a lot of stuff to offer. Alongside the main story, you'll occasionally meet strangers - paleontologists, beggars, other outlaws on the run as well as an occasional NPC in need of help, their variety tends to be interesting and creative from time to time - there was an instance where I was able to watch a doctor amputate an NPCs left arm. Unfortunately, these seem to be too scripted and I found myself in a few occasions where I helped a prisoner on the run and left the area before he was able to speak to me, only to cross the path with the exact same NPC and the exact same problem a few hours later, just in a different place. Eventually, I helped him again and waited for him to finish his line in order to avoid the same meetup again.People can be weird at times and riding a horse often caused encounters with strangers who greet me. The game provides a fun option to talk to any NPC, but I found myself avoiding this since you can never really know what Arthur is going to say next, no matter whether it's positive or not. Random NPCs sometimes greet you in the wild, and while I'd gladly send some greetings back, it feels a bit too much work to stop the horse from riding, focus on the NPC who may already left and then talk to them. At the end of the day, it's the littlest interactions that truly magnify the experience. There was an instance in the camp where two characters had a discussion whether the gang is losing their way and after few arguments, Hosea turned to me and ask me of "my" opinion.The controls are binded the way they are natural, but there are often really unresponsive, especially while riding a horse. The horse sometimes may or may not slip over anything. The bond with your horse is important, since a it will result in both better and easier controls as well as the distance within you can call it. If it's far away, you'll have to wait for the horse to physically return to you. Stealing a horse will mark it as a temporary one, and a nice touch was seeing how the game will remember its existence and the last place you left it the next time you play. Combat, on the other hand, feels really good and it has the positive elements of GTA5's with some improvements. Guns will have lower stats if they are not cleaned, but they won't be low enough for most players to care.The weather can change randomly within a few seconds and when it does, colder weather will impact your health, so you allegedly need to wear clothes intended for the current temperature. Arthur's actions won't have an impact on the story, but depending on the honor level, the same cutscene will play out differently. One of the things that impact the honor level is the so-called "witness system" - unfortunately, RDR2 suffers from the GTA police effect. The law will magically know you for killing a person in the middle of nowhere which usually results in a randomly spawned traveler running away to tell the sheriff. Every step of the horse, every animation, every plant and rock you come across are meant to immerse you into its beautiful open world, and it's incredible to see that the game succeeds in doing that more than often. The lighting is just phenomenal and it works really well. The game features a wide range of terrains - from the foggy and snowy mountains all the way to the swamps filled with alligators, it never ever felt repetitive. Even visiting the exact same spot feels like a totally new place. Rockstar has really inducted the power of QUIXEL's Megascans in a proper way and the result is just wonderful.The details of each gun and character is astonishing. The characters will be covered in mud if not cleaned, their health will worsen and Arthur's face and animation will changed based on his health or if he got attacked by someone. The skin may be brighter and reddish on sunlight and both mud and snow will have footprints if walked on.There's an outstanding cast of talented voice actors featured in RDR2; Rob Wiethoff and Benjamin Byron Davis reprise their roles as John Marston and Dutch van der Linde, respectively. The main character is portrayed by Roger Clark and he delivers the line wonderfully most of the time - it's a performance of a lifetime. The sound of the guns is great as well and has a nice few touches depending on the origin and area of the gunshot, so it will sound different indoors and outdoors.2010's Red Dead Redemption had entering Mexico playing "Far Away" by Jose Gonzalez, and that is one of the most wonderful moments in all of gaming. While "Far Away" doesn't return here, there is a similar equivalent - D'Angelo's "Unshaken", and it works well for RDR2's setting. Generally, Rockstar's music choice is top notch and I loved every bit of it.If anyone cares, here's some numbers:

author: NJ
review: Personal Rating: 10/10I was totally excited when the game was finally released on PC. After nearly 10 years of waiting for the sucessor, it definitively paid off, the  game is  astonishing. The story and dialogues of individual characters are amazingly written. You can take your time with the story, explore many locations, or side missions which tell other interesting stories. As far as you can go, you can also do a lot of nonsense, caution here, because due to the high level of realism of NPCs’, they remember nearly every little detail of you (clothing, horse etc.) Nevertheless, which was also known, the game also has its issues. The game is very large and extensive that the developers have actually forgotten, to explain things a lot more precisely, which were relevant for gameplay. Of course there were also many PC bugs, but this shouldn't matter in terms of the game itself, but was a mistake by the developers. Since the game has definitely laid a new foundation for realism in games, I think that there are lovers or dislikes depending on the player. For me, it was great. In my opinion, one of the best games over the past 10 years.

author: Kartikeya0807
review: Playing as Arthur Morgan, arguably one of the best gaming protagonists of all times, watching him get through all these struggles with his gang falling apart, people dying around, and his own personal battle for his health is what takes Red Dead 2 on a different level of gaming. I wont be the first person to say this but the game literally felt *alive*. Each npc moving around has its own personal life which it carries out over and over again, the animals react to you and the surrounding almost as if it is actually happening in real life. The attention to detail Rockstar put into this game is just marvelous. The story, the scenery, the gameplay is all just perfect and fits in extremely well. I've heard people say that the game is *slow* or just calling it a *Cowboy GTA*. I believe that the game actually tries to convey its story like a movie, In the first chapter, it sets up characters and lays down there traits and how they react to certain situations. Watching Dutch Van Der Linde, John Marston, Javier Escuella and Bill Williamson is certainly nostalgic and reminds how RDR1 was a Masterpiece too. The slow gameplay is needed to sets up the amount of chaos that's gonna happen towards the end. The major difference between RDR and GTA is that the latter is a blockbuster action movie with an okay enough story while the former is a slow paced Scorcese movie with cinematic moments and an amazing story and setting. Overall Red Dead Redemption 2 is a masterpiece 10/10 Edit: People complaining about fast travel is a valid point as game doesnt exactly explain how to use it properly. Basically you just need to set up your campfire outside any city and you can fast travel back to any loaction that you've been too. Hope it helps

author: DRACER
review: Absolutely amazing work and effort put in by Rockstar Games. This review is spoiler free so you can read this without worry.Graphics: The game's graphics are absolutely spectacular, especially when you finish the first chapter of the game. The lighting and fog effects are unbelievably good. The god ray effects in forests are realistic. Nighttime lighting is realistic as the moonlight spreads over the whole area instead of being a light in the sky. Character clothes have great attention to detail, along with the fur on animals, and mud effects in towns.Gameplay: The gameplay can be a bit of a slow burn at the start, but once the first chapter is done, the gameplay becomes less restricting, and continues to do so as you progress forward. The Dead-Eye system, which is a character ability to slow down time when shooting, isn't like regular slow-mo shooting, but you can tag targets to automatically shoot them when you press the shoot button. The gameplay is also very realistic as you have to maintain your guns to keep them working effectively (they can jam if you don't) and you also have to bathe regularly to keep yourself clean, eat regularly (but not too much at a time) to keep your weight in check and also you have to sleep and eat regularly to maintain your cores. The 3 cores (Health, Stamina and Dead-Eye) decide how fast their respective attribute regenerates. If you have full cores, the attributes will regenerate at the fastest possible rate. Another mechanic is horse bonding and to do this you have to groom, feed and be kind to your horse to bond to the maximum level i.e level 4. You also have to feed your horse regularly so they don't starve. All this may be confusing at first, and may be tedious to some, but you'll figure it out once you start playing the gameDetails: I could go on and on about this. Horse balls expand/contract based on the weather, wolves mourn other wolves' death, constellations in the sky are 100% accurate. You drown if you swim too long, boats sink if a hole is shot in them, you pass out if you drink too much alcohol, you can vomit if you eat too much. Snow, mud and blood can get stuck on your character's clothes, and clothes only get wet up to the part they have been inside the water. Also, let's not forget the great random encounters in this game.Story and side missions: The story is possibly one of the best ones in videogames. I won't write much about this as it's filled with spoilers, but rest assured, if you pay attention to the story, you will enjoy the game to its fullest. Coming to the other thing, side missions are often humorous and enjoyable, and are usually as good as the main story. Make sure to do side quests around the same pace as the main story.Characters: The characters are quite amazing. People who only played the first game may not like Arthur at first, but trust me, he is amazing. Then there's the iconic John Marston who isn't as great as he was as he is still young and foolish. We also have the charismatic Dutch Van Der Linde as the leader of the gang, and Bill and Javier as guns on heists. Other returning characters include Abigail Roberts/Marston and a 4 year old Jack Marston. There are also a lot of new characters like Hosea Matthews, Micah Bell, Lenny Summers, Charles Smith etc, who you all don't know at the start, but eventually come to form an opinion and virtual bond with them.I could go on and on but I'll just let you experience the rest. It is a 10/10 game made by the legendary company Rockstar Games, so rest assured, it's worth every single penny.Happy trails My Rating for this game - 9.5/10

author: Madsonium
review: What could have I say. I recommend this game to everyone. It is just... wow.

author: Ke1N
review: Red Dead Redemption II was definitely one of the best experiences that I ever had in a video game.I bought the title day one on the PS4 and enjoyed almost every part of Arthur and the gang’s adventures. The story was enthralling and I remained interested in understanding what exactly went so wrong, that we got the “hell bent on revenge” John Marston in the first game (the second game is actually acting as a prequel).The attention the detail was amazing. Rockstar completely nailed every little thing and managed to make it feel not so tedious, I hugely enjoyed every realistic aspect of the game. The ability to have a “short conversation” with strangers, the fact that you and your clothes get dirty so you need to take a bath and clean them.  People will also react differently to you if you are wearing dirty clothes.Also, the fact that when your horse is dirty it impacts its stamina and you need to take care of him as well. These little things are doing a really good job of making the world feel alive.As with every other Rockstar game you have complete control (out of missions) in the world. You can explore as much, as you like. You can do various side missions and participate in a lot of the classic mini games that were present in the original. The amount of shows and attractions that you can visit is also really impressive, especially when you get to St. Denis, the performances there are amazing.The setting is amazingly done, I still remember the chills that I had when I played Red Dead Redemption 1 and went to Mexico, they are several plot points here that left the same or maybe even bigger impression on me. I just love the Wild West era.Graphically the game looks stunning, it looks even better on PC, of course from what I’ve seen so far. I understand that there were some issues with the port, welp I guess that’s what the 1 month of Epic exclusivity is for, to test and tweak the bugs, so that we can get a good release on the real platforms. The optimization sure seems strange at best, but unfortunately this has become a tradition with Rockstar ports… (it speaks a lot that the top reviews are all users posting fixes for crashing or other technical problems)They continue to treat the PC market as “second hand customers”, and sadly this is not changing soon.My only real gripe with this game is how “limited” the world feels when you are doing a “scripted” story mission. The game holds your hand too much on the story points, the freedom that you were having in the open world disappears and you need to follow the path that was set by the developers. You can’t do most of the things your way, which is kind of strange because it feels really limiting. I understand that they probably do that as part of the “cinematic” experience, but a big part of Rockstar games in the past was the complete freedom that you were having to fully create your own experience.I’m looking forward to playing the game - 1 year later with keyboard and mouse and with better graphics. I don’t know if it’s worth 60 bucks right now, based on the fact that it’s more than a year since the official console release, but if you are looking for a great story with an amazing open world, look no more.(I didn’t write anything about the online part, because I’m not familiar with it, I treated this game purely as a single player experience. Maybe I will check the online someday.)

author: Sonic Punk
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is the game that sets a new bar for all open world games. It took me around 190 hours to complete this amazing journey with 87% completion and I still have some side missions and unexplored lands left. The game is a prequel to Red Dead Redemption, so even if you didn't play the first one you can perfectly enjoy the ride and start hoping for a remake. If you played the first RDR though, you will definitely get the best experience, as some characters return and the ending part of the story is so connected to RDR that you will get emotional. There are two game modes available: story and online (which I barely touched). I would say that, even without the online part, the game is worth every single cent. Since it's a massive game, it's hard to write a proper review without taking every single aspect in consideration.Once again Rockstar elaborates its amazing version of the frontier depicting a world at the edge of civilization where there's no longer place for outlaws and gunslingers. Everything is narrated through the eyes of Arthur Morgan, a member of the Van Der Linde gang. It takes quite some time to introduce story, characters and world events, but it always feels natural. You will enjoy the story better if you treat the gang as your family, talking to them, fullfilling their requests, doing activities together. There are also some choices you can make that will indeed change dialogue lines, cutscenes and even unlock more story missions, so choose wisely when someone asks you to help. You will also be able to increase or lower your level of honor, depending on your actions, and that will affect how the other gang members react and talk about you.Speaking about longevity and replay value, every story mission has some challenges that will reward you with a bronze, silver or gold medal. Sadly most of these challenges require you to complete missions in the shortest time possible, which I think it's a wrong game design choice, 'cause the game is slow paced and you will get so absorbed by the dialogues that you won't rush just to get some medals. It adds some replayability but personally I don't feel like getting all the gold medals.The gameplay is as realistic and immersive as it could be: opening drawers, skinning an animal, tying your horse, picking weapons, looting corpses and much more. Everything has its own command, takes its own time and it's fully animated, with a level of detail that I never saw in any other open world game. You can even interact with all NPCs, though you will often have only three options: talk, provoke and rob. While most of NPCs will eventually start to repeat the same dialogues, this interaction is really useful with particular strangers, random encounters, gang members, animals and more. It's a kind of interaction that is based on context, so it's really important to keep an eye on the things you can say or do depending on the situation.Like the previous game, there's a level of honor connected to your actions. It helps define what kind of person you want Arthur Morgan to be, although his story is already written, so it's more about how he behaves and what others think of him.Horse riding is the best one I've seen in a videogame: realistic, social and not buggy. You can capture horses, buy and sell them. You need to take good care of your horse if you want to increase his stats and your bonding level which will unlock new riding abilities. Be careful though, your horse can be stolen or killed (you can revive him using a special medicine if it's not too late). Small tip: you can talk while riding, no need to get off your horse. You can also drive boats and trains.Gunplay is good. It's simple, but with all the available weapons you can get really creative. Not just guns but also arrows, throwing knives, explosives etc. You can also customize weapons and outfits of course. There's an Aim Assist feature that you can reduce or disable if you don't like. Red Dead also uses the Dead Eye system, which allows to slow down time and manually target your enemies before auto-shooting them all.AI is very good. During combat I've seen not only enemies taking cover and trying to flank you, but also trying to stab or disarm you. Enemies also react realistically when shot, they can lose their hats and get injured. Outside from combat, AI does a great job too. NPCs start looking at you if you follow them, asking what you want. People looking at you the first time you enter a saloon. Small things like this really help increasing the immersion.The world of RDR 2 is one of the biggest and most detailed I have ever seen. Every single region has its own unique beauty and wildlife: different forests, towns, mountains, deserts. The weather system is also incredible. You can tell when it's about to rain, you can hear thunders at distance, you can see your horse getting scared, the wind moving grass and leaves around you. RDR 2 open world is truly an amazing experience. As always, exploration is a key element. It rewards you in different ways:That's just a short recap, there's so much to do that you will never get bored.Generally speaking, soundtrack and sound design are great. The game has this random soundtrack system that selects the music depending on the place and the mood, which I think is amazing.Despite what others might say, the game is really well optimized. Even medium settings look amazing, but being able to play the game at higher settings is breathtaking. In any case there are so many options to tweak that you can find the perfect balance between graphic quality and performance, it just needs some testing.One thing though. In the prologue area you might get a better performance due to the fact that you can't roam in the open world for story reasons, so you will only have a real idea of your performance after the prologue (which could take more than 2 hours).The only cons I could think of is the Rockstar Launcher. It's awful and it can give you problems if you want to start the game offline.RDO is a real Westworld experience. It shares the same huge map, so if you don't want to get spoilers about locations, I would suggest to play it only after finishing the main story, or at least exploring most of the map. There's a storyline that introduces you the online mechanics. There are co-op missions, side activities, co-op and pvp events, but hopefully Rockstar will keep adding more. Like GTA Online, the game includes microtransactions. It can be really grindy if you want to buy expensive horses and outfits and they probably hope you will buy some gold bars using real money.If you want to buy the game just for Red Dead Online, don't.With its living open world and its amazing story Red Dead Redemption 2 offers a true western experience you won't find in any other game.

author: Machiavelli
review: So I spend 90 hours in one week on this game... Am I mad?Background:Red Dead Redemption 2 is an action-adventure, open world game set in a wild west scenario. As its name suggests, the game is part of the Red Dead series and a prequel to Red Dead Redemption. You play as Arthur Morgan, an enforcer of the Dutch van der Linde gang. After a job went horribly wrong, the gang has to run and pick up the pieces to be able to leave the country for good.Opinion on the game:Lets get to it. This game is one of the greatest open world games ever. And I mean that literally. The world you play in is huge, the regions vary from a cold Rocky Mountain environment over the humid swamps of Florida to the arid and hot dessert wasteland of Texas. The world is so vast but yet full of life. Even in the remotest dessert areas or on the coldest mountain tops, you never get the impression that you would be alone in an empty world. Rockstar managed to put life into this game with the incredible diversity in the animal and plant fauna, the interaction with others and the map design in general. Especially the great contrast between the deadly wilderness and the life in all the small villages and towns really adds to the game's capability of immersing the player into a world as it could have been in the late 19th century in the wild west. A big contributing factor is that with exception of one character (to whom I come to later), all pro- and antagonists are credible, which is partly due the fact that they were played by real life actors.So the game is huge, not only in terms of space (on your drive) but also in terms of how mauch playtime you can get out of it. The single player camapign alone without doing any sidequests will take you at least 15 hours.The graphic and sound design are also incredible. There was one instance where I was in the desert during a severe storm. (You have a dynamic weather btw) The lighting and sound effects were so impressive that I was just standing in the midst of the storm for 3 minutes straight watching how the rain affected the wild life and environment around me. One of my all time favourite moments in playing video games was riding through Saint Denis at night. A post-Victorian era industralized city resembling the likes of what is now New Orleans. On the one hand, you see the ones profiting from the industrialization and just a few streets further you experience the lifes of the people that did not manage to cope with these changes. You see the snobbery and corruption, you see the poverty and you get a perfect understanding of why certain elements in the population reject the society this era produced.The interaction with NPCs is nothing but outstanding. You can talk to practically anyone and the responses will be always somewhat different. Some will even tell you their life stories if you dont leave in time. And others may try to rob and kill you...The protagonist(s) you play have the most important trait that I value the most in a video game character. And that is credibility. Just by playing the game, you understand why they make the decisions they make. And why they change the way they change. Rockstar has done a great job with that and this also includes the antagonists.So in summary, the gameplay experience this game provides is amazing. I can only think of two to maybe three other games that managed to immerse me into their world in a way that RDR 2 accomplished. It really ticks all the boxes so far but is it a perfect game?Even though I would really like to give this game a 10/10, I cant. There are two major things holding it back. One is the character I previously mentioned. Unfortunately, this character (Sadie Adler) feels so forced into the game since she is written way too over the top and exaggerated. This is why whenever you interact with her, she manages to destory single-handedly all the immersion created by the entirety of all the other game elements. Thats a real shame, especially since she is way more present in the last chapters of the game and really soured my gaming experience towards the end. Plus, her voice is so annyoing that at some point, I just skipped all the dialoge with her.The second aspect (and arguably or objectivley the more important one) is the fact that this game (on PC) is just a console port. Which Rockstar is not really famous for, and this is for good reason. This game is liable to crashing and freezing. Once you have to replay 30 minute story missions that basically only consist of walking and talking, you get somewhat frustrated. For a AAA title, the amount of crashing is just not acceptable. Furthermore, the menus, UI and also the interactions with objects can be clunky. This game was designed for consoles and you feel it every minute you play. Another issue is that this game is really hardware hungry/badly optimized, especially so if you want to crank up your graphics settings. Eg, I got an RTX 3070 and a Ryzen 5 5600X and I struggle to achieve 40 fps on ultra settings in full HD. Apart from that, there are also notable bugs and glitches in the game but I wont consider them in the final rating. This is because it is just ridiuclous to assume that anyone could create a world as huge and impressive as this game without having a small amount of bugs in it as well.Summary:In conclusion, this game is astonishing. If you have any interest in western themed scenaria, like open world games or prefer story driven games in general, get this game! You will not regret it. (Or maybe dont if you have a potato PC, otherwise the game might not even launch in the first place) Despite its shortcomings, it is easily in the top 3 games Ive ever played. There are only a few games out there, that achieve a comparable level of immersion and authenticity. Considering everything I stated above, I give RDR 2 9.8/10. This is a Game of the Generation contender, nothing short of that. Period. So maybe I might not be mad after all. Well, at least not completely....

author: ifear
review: There's so much to do, and hardly any of it is fun.So much time and effort has gone into crafting intricate systems that are tedious to use (oh, I'll set a camp - but not here, as it's not the wilderness - then cook some pieces of meat one at a time so I can  not die), realism that interferes with enjoyment (yes, horses can throw you off and run away when a predator is near, but it's irritating every time), story missions that force you to ignore all the tools and approaches you've been given (we want you to use this slow horse for this one, so your own horse won't come when called for no good mechanical or narrative reason), and countless other ideas that make sense only if you ignore that games are meant to be enjoyed.Your weapons disappear back onto your horse constantly - when you rest, when there's a cut scene, etc. etc. - leaving you with only pistols during a mission all too often.But above all, the thing that ruins what has so much potential to be a good (or even great) game is the wanted system - jostling someone by accident can make them hostile, accidentally pointing a gun at someone can mean you're disturbing the peace, shooting a predator near a witness can do the same, and so on; the same action can give you positive karma or set the law after you, without the distinction ever being clear ahead of time; and once you're in the cycle of being wanted, being chased, etc. there are countless hoops to jump through before you can get back to playing the game without being shot (unless you're playing the game as a pure shooter, which is unlikely as the combat mechanics are too weak to hold up on their own) - and the rules that govern them are wholly inconsistent. Sometimes I'm wanted for a crime when there was no-one for miles around to witness it - there's just no way to avoid being wanted, and it's no fun.The first Red Dead Redemption was a joy to play. This one is a chore. I keep playing as it constantly feels like the fun is just around the corner, but it never is.

author: Vlad 254
review: The prequel to Red Dead RedemptionMaybe you want action, maybe you need a chill game for a break in the action (this game has both). This game has it all and regardless if you played the first RDR or not you'll find this game is absolutely amazing, I'd go so far as to say a masterpiece. Sometimes there is more story than action but that's not to say it's a boring game at all and the story is simply superb. That said you do have control of how much action you want vs story. The game has stunning graphics, great gameplay, it's immersive and you truly get attached to the characters in the Van der Linde gang. I'd say Rockstar has mastered open world gaming with RDR2 which is a true western right down to the gun and saloon fights as well as the train and stage coach robberies. Call it an RPG where there are no skill or perk trees to put points in to at each level up as there is no character level system. You earn XP in 3 attributes, Health, Stamina, and an excellent aiming system called Dead Eye which are all leveled separately. You level up your stats in a learning-by-doing type system. You must do certain physical actions, such as sprinting to increase stamina, rowing a boat to increase health and shooting to increase dead eye. The map is massive. There is also a Honor rank which you control with good or bad deeds or even things like doing chores if you so choose. There are potions and food to control your health and weight and of course camping, cooking, even skining animals. In short this game is incredible. The game does a good job with both funny and touching moments I'm already looking forward to another playthrough where I make different choices. Iv'e played about 100 hours so far on my RTX 2070 with an i7-8700 CPU and have encountered zero bugs. I give this game a 10/10!

author: ru$h
review: Great Music, Great gameplay, Great Story Great Acting, this is truly a master piece of video gaming I can only fault it on perhaps having a bit to much in the gameplay department as to make it a bit overwhelming at times. This game really puts you in the world of the old west and allows you to relive your greatest old west and makes you feel like part of that world. Have played the 1st part on console and have been waiting for it to release on PC since it was announce and boy it was worth the wait.Writing 10/10Sound 10/10Graphics 10/10Gameplay 9/10Acting 10/10The story was so breath taking and progressed beautifully showing the current adventures of an outlaw who has lived a life violence and sorrow. As the story progresses you learn even more about the character which may or may not make you feel for him. The story present many chances for big choices to be made which impact whether the character is good or bad. The soundtrack is impressive and really brings the story to life and greatly aided in bringing me to tears several times.  Game play was great and really inventive but at times it felt like a lot. In the end the acting greatly benefited the overall story and really added to the motion i think all the actors deserve a pat on the back. The Graphics of course was stunning the detail was almost felt impossible it really makes the game stand out.

author: Raagaception
review: For some reason, I can't connect to Rockstar Social Club from India AT ALL. I needed to use a VPN to make an account and login. It would be fine if it was a one time affair; but the game needs to be connected to Social Club 24/7 or else it won't ever start up, and give an "Activation Required" screen. Since being connected to a VPN at all times isn't feasible just for a single player experience, can't recommend this unless you're able to access Social Club from your device. 0/10 for the anti-customer DRM experience, I'm sure it would be a great game if I could actually play what I paid for.

author: Gunter Severloh
review: Love this game!   Going to list some good and bad points:Good Points:==========- Graphically game is stunning, that is if you have the hardware to boot, I'm running the game on an- i7 -700k 4.20 cpu- EVGA Geforce RTX 2060 12gb- 32gb ram 3600mhz- 1 TB SSD- 4 500gb SSD's- PSU 1000wGame is smooth for me no hiccups, or stutters.   If you have low specs, low ram, no SSD, low end system then i suggest not buying the game, you not only may not be able to play it, but then the quality, and performance would be crap, and you would be frustrated because its not going to run like it should, so either upgrade ... seriously or dont by it, trust me, i've seen reviews where people complain the game runs like crap, yet they have crap hardware and they blame the game for their own lack, dont do it!- Graphics again -==============I use a Reshade ---> It seriously changed how my game looks without any performance impact.  Most of my settings are in ultra except for a few.- Gameplay -===========You can play in 1st & 3rd person! i love open world, there is alot of freedom, and then there is not depending, some things i wish it was just like skyrim, open, unrestricted, drop, pickup what you like, even instead of a story, i would have preferred to have a character creation like it is online.       Besides the hunting, fishing, looting, camping, and exploring, the world has amazing detail, it seems fairly authentic to how it looked back in the day, like i would know but from documentaries, pics, ect. i'd say it seems legit.          The weapons are pretty cool overall, sound, look, and function, i dislike the automatic reload, the automatic fill my gun up with bullets when i shot 4 and have 2 remaining and i holster the gun and then pull it out and find a little gremlin has filled the gun for me, wtf    You can change that with a mod ;)     Deadeye, i dont use it, i play hudless, since im an Arma fan and used to simulations, thats how i prefer it, i dont care for the deadeye, i think its just cheating, and its a fools tool, for me it breaks the immersion so im happy that you can have the option to not use it, i prefer looking at the map and using my brain. I prefer the challenge and the threat it makes you think about your tactics, and how to overcome or go about doing something.- NPC's / AI  -===========    The fact that NPC's respond to you based on what you do, what you say ect,. is to me the 1st i have experienced in any game, i find it incredibly immersive, i do wish there was a bit more to it, like go into further dialogue with them, but if you keep hitting greet, or even antagonize it will go a bit further.    NPC's remember you, even after you haven't been around for a while, thats all of them, if they've seen you before, if you have good honor they respond accordingly, this to me is very refreshing in a game, it makes it more as i said alive, immersive, but more interactive, also effects you emotionally to a degree.- Animals, Hunting,Fishing, other things related -=====================================  I mostly do hunting, and fishing, skinning animals is pretty realistic, when i skinned my first animal it was a bit gruesome to see but i got used to it, i actually felt sorry, empathetic, sad for the animals when i shot them as they do respond, i mean they cry out in pain if they are wounded, its scary real where you feel guilty, like you feel bad to have done that.    Of course you know its a game too, so still for a game to stimulate those feelings really adds to the immersion.  The predators .... Scary!  Wolves, bears, watch out for them, be ready!!!   i dont want to say they are rare but when you do come apon them your horse will get antsy and start going crazy, best get off him and find high ground with a view and some distance.   Been killed a number of times by wolves, cougars, and bears, but most encounters were warded off or i ran.    Animals are "alive" they respond like they would in real life (to a point, im no expert but its believable), predators are scary, either run like the wind or kill them!  Other animals, may either ram you, bite you, or run from you, so watch your step!- Horses -========    Horses are awesome, customize them, gear/equipment like saddle ect,. even their tail, ect,. treat your horse with respect, feed them, pat them, wash/brush them, and you will bond with them, ya its that real, theres 4 levels of bonding, after level 2 they respond to commands, you can tell them to stay, and whistle for them provided their within hearing range of you.   I have 3 horses, i use all 3 at the same time, you can name them too, and tell them to follow me, and stay when i need them too.        You can individually call them, tell them to stay, ect,. but i use all 3 for hunting, for carrying pelts, and hides which will gain you more money when you sell them.   Just remember your horse is everything in this game, ya you can run everywhere on foot but then why would you, the horse is pretty realistic and feels very immersive, its like riding a real horse, and yes i did when i was a kid.- Story / Game -=============Story is pretty interesting, the game is fairly linear up til you get to chapter 2, as its made to be an immersive story tutorial you just dont know it, its pretty cool how they do it.   There are missions, the main quest missions with the gang your with are what progresses chapters, the story is immersive and really brings you into the game and characters emotionally, theres alot there!- Bad Points -===========- Game can be linear with some missions, overall its free roam.- I wish the game had more customization for your character instead of a set character, otherwise you can change the look of your character (Arthur Morgan)I would rather have to create a character and spend 1-2hrs on features, looks, ect,. then just go with it, however your character's hair, beard does grow, and can be long, and you can get haircuts and shave to how you want to look, change your clothes, and there are many other customization's for weapons, gear and for the horse so thats good at least.- Not everything is interactive.- I hate in some instances when you setup camp in a certain spot (unlike skyrim camp mod) where you camp, you dont end up there, its close though.There is a mod where you can camp anywhere so if you dont plan to play online and like camping get that mod!- Honor system needs some tweaking  - dont loot knocked out people = bad honor, anddont kill horses are the two most things imo that lowers honor quickly, unless your a straight up outlaw then thats up to you.- Time can be a bit "fast" and the weather goes with it, i mean its not super fast, but the day change still takes quite a bit, You can change it with a trainer, a good one is one that comes with scripthook rdr2 weather its pretty cool too.- Deadeye as said before to me is stupid, it breaks the immersion, i wish it weren't in the game but i dont use it so thats good enough.=========Idk what else to say here, its a good game if you have the hardware and if your into westerns, if you like western movies, or even old history then this game will be for you.=========LastlyWatch this video, its 37min long, but it goes into detail, its funny as hell, but its the truth, if you have any experience with Rockstar's game this guy tells the truth on how RDR2 plays he nails it:Here are some resources for the game:Mod Websites===========Nexus - RDR2Game GuideMapsFull mapInteractive RDR2 Map

author: ZemunBRE
review: One of THE games I was super hyped turned out to be disaster experience.To explain more about this, let's start with good things.Graphic is super awesome, you will get sucked in to the ambient of game from minute one.When at it, its well optimized and can be playable at most today PC's, if not then sorry reader you should upgrade your rig long time ago.World/map is fairly big and will take you hours and hours to explore, what is especially great is that it is full of random events and encounters with npc's that will reward you if you decide to help them.Sounds, pretty much as graphic, music and voice acting are top notch, Rockstar didn't cut the budget in it :)Gameplay, hmm well, maybe I was overhyped when hearing from friends how immersive and deep story is... Sorry friends but I did not get that feeling. After beating the story and plenty of side quests (not all) that took me over 55-60 hours, only thing in my head is WHY the hell are 99% characters so stupid.People were intelligent back then same as today, but the amount of stupidity and retarded actions in this game is unreal. I didn't feel well playing the game where main character and his friends had IQ lower than outside temperature, and yes it's winter.... In any case amount of playtime and replayability  justify the price of the game, that is for singleplayer/story mode.Now the major thing, WHY negative review?!I do not understand how is it possible for a Rockstar, AAA dev/publisher multimilionarebiollionaretrillionare company  to allow themselves to release the game that is NOT working properly.First there are random crashes in singleplayer, some players experience it more some the less, I was lucky that I had maybe 5 crashes in interval of 50-60 hours, that was tolerable.However, ONLINE, that's the trick, it keep crashing,crashing and crashing due Rockstar end, it crash you in middle of mission, it crash you with inventory and horse full of goods that ofc disappear... you get the picture.WORST part on this subject is that I saw people complaining about this 0x20010006 error BS for over 7 months.... 7 FU MONTHS.... that brings be to conclusion that it may never be fixed.P.S. Almost forgot, loads of cheaters, in almost every event, you get at least one or two... god mode on, aim on... If I didn't see it with my own eyes I'd say yeah Im bad, they were better, but after shooting at man over and over again and his hp is stucked at full not to mention legit scores such as level 20 with 50kills 0 deaths.... convinced me again that Rockstar anti-cheat is a joke same as in gta5.And worst thing about this is that you cant report players after event is over, only in middle of it. Thats it from me :D But yeah it's great game, hopefully they will fix it in future.UPDATE 10/1/2022Just installed the game again to see if I can enjoy it some more... aaaand I'm happy to see that connection has been fixed and It's playable. HOWEVER still sea of lowlife cheaters, it's impossible to play anything online  involving shooting, unless you have a cheater in your squad too. Still remains negative review.

author: sky
review: With its amazing open-world, well-written story and deep characters, Red Dead Redemption II is a roller-coaster full of emotions. Controls may feel a bit clunky at times, but still this is a masterpiece.And if you want to play it prepare youre tissue

author: STRIX
review: Hell hath no furry. Rough times in history always created heroes and villains. But sometimes fate marks the same person for both. If you want a glimpse into the history of USA, this game is ready to bring it closer with truth, violence, emotions, grace, hate, love, struggle, happiness, survival, trust, despair and wilderness all together. A game well done indeed, it was worth every penny.- The third and the best entry in the Red Dead series.- Beautiful graphics and masterful voice acting, 4K and HDR support.- Open world and plenty of content (the main story accounts for only about 60% of the content).- The game spans across five fictional states in USA, beautifully modeled with wild life, gorgeous scenery and weather, bandits and cities.- Wonderful, emotional, non-repetitive, epic main story that makes you fall and care for the main character and pushes you to see what is coming next.- Hundreds of side quests to feed an explorer's ego.- Adequate soundtrack and environmental sound effects.- Smooth gameplay with no bugs.- Unexpected plot twists masterfully embedded into the narrative.- You really get to feel how was like to live and fight for survival in the Western, Midwestern, and Southern United States around 1899 and you may even understand why outlaws actually had no choice but to become outlaws.- Incomplete ultrawide support (cinematic camera and cutscenes can be seen without black bars only if you used a third-party mod - thx @ROSE for that)- Chapters 1, 5 and 6 are by far the most interesting. Parts of Chapters 2, 3 and 4 are a bit boring, as well as part of the two Epilogue stories- A lot of riding and talking. And I mean... A LOT.- Maybe more camp upgrades would be desirable.

author: 💕𝓢𝓱𝓪𝓭𝓸𝔀🐾
review: My love for GTA-4 & 5, got me to get this, regardless of the Steam reviews at launch. I had no issues then, and I don't have them now. Before I bought it, I made sure my GTA-5 was still in working order. I had to reconfirm my E-Mail address, but that only took 2 minutes. It's been quite some time since I played, and I just didn't want to buy the game, and find out something odd happened to my R* account, as has been reported by a few people.I had only one crash, and that was the very first launch of the game. So I adjusted my Graphics Card a tad, and there have been no issues to report. You don't really need Ultra Settings on everything. So I knocked a couple down a notch. I'm not going to bother listing my FPS, because I totally hate the  that lurk around out there, but the game runs nice, and smooth for me, and my benchmark test ran just fine. In-fact, better than I expected.I also got the  to work properly without any lag, or stuttering. No need to fiddle around with files placing this here, and that there, as noted on the forum. Now I can go into the games  and take some nice pics.I like the grit of Westerns (movies or games), and this game is a real treat for me to play. The story thus far is engaging, and the graphics are superb once you get the right mix. I only play  so you'll have to go elsewhere for a review on Coop/MP.So, if you've got the money, give it a try. This was an early Christmas Gift for myself, and I'm not regretting the purchase price for the Special Edition.

author: Anasetsuken
review: Cannot get the game to run, and apparently a large number of others can't as well. When I launch from Steam the game crashes. When I try to start from Rockstar Launcher, it shows game is not linked to my account. All troubleshooting tried both from Rockstar and discussion forms are still not working. Will be refunding soon unless there is a resolution/patch provided.**Edit: FixedSaw someone else post to try removing usb controller from pc, and it worked. Why is this even a game breaking issue?I am playing story mode now it is running great so far. Not having any fps issues like some others are, I have about 80-90fps on average. (i7-7700k/1080ti) Was very excited when this was originally announced and glad it is finally working. Will continue to update review as I go along.

author: Gabi27
review: I have this game on PS4 too, and I gotta say, it's a very nice, story rich, triple A game that brings you into the life of an outlaw and you gotta survive somehow, either by doing good things and raising your honor level or killing bad guys and stealing from them, but forming a bad honor level. You decide. The characters are all amazing in my opinion, of course the most loved one is Arthur because you form a bond with him the more you play the game. So after all, it's a very good game to play, if you'd like to feel like you're in the Wild West, than this game is for you.I know some people have technical issues with the game, but personally, the only issue I had so far was an infinite loading screen that occurred in RDO. Hopefully R* will patch these bugs asap and we'll have a wonderful, functional masterpiece.

author: カト [Kato]
review: As far as I can tell, a lot of hard work and good thought went into this game.The world is extremely detailed, multifaceted and authentically designed.The graphic implementation - be it the water-, particle- or light effects - is breathtaking.Unfortunately, as much as I love this game, I have a hard time recommending it.The reason for this are the technical difficulties that make Red Dead Redemption 2 almost unplayable.I, like countless other players, am plagued by regular crashes that just can't be fixed.Spread over several days, I have now more than 15 hours on the clock and sadly just finished the first mission.Continuing to complete the story mode is a Sisyphean task which I am not willing to take on, since every crash within an ongoing mission forces me to replay the whole thing.After trawling countless forums and guides, I still haven't been able to fix RDR2 and run it for a long period of time without the whole game just crashing. Even though I know that the problem is often sitting behind the screen, in this particular case I can say with a great certainty that I have done everything in my power to get the game running stably.(...Searching for corrupt files; switching between Vulcan and Dx12; testing the graphic settings; using health care and 'SFC /scannow' in cmd etc.; using DDU to freshly reinstall my drivers; using steam commands as '-ignorepipelinecache'; etc etc etc...)I really want to like this game and have spent much more time then I would like to admit trying to fix this mess Rockstar Games has released but after 15 hours even I surrender.I hope to get this game working one day, but my patience is not endless and it has now reached its limit.

author: Aiden
review: This game is perfect in every way and the main character Arthur Morgan is easily one of the best characters made in video game history. The narrative is beautiful and emotional that it makes you the player connected with almost every single character you meet in the game and actually care for them as if they're people you know in real life. The soundtrack chosen for the main menu, gameplay, cutscenes, and many different missions are amazing and are perfectly timed it gives you chills. The gameplay is detailed where you would do many things realistically and it's extremely fun. The graphics and details are just unbelievable it will really amaze you so much that it makes you stop and look at your surroundings just like in Witcher 3: The Wild Hunt. Red Dead Redemption 2 is no doubt the best Rockstar games has ever made so far. I hope Rockstar games keep getting better like they always do in the past 20 years and make more games like this that engages the players into its world and story . 100/10

The pinnacle of gaming. What every game should strive for. Literally everything is finely made, and fits together, making it a marvelous experience. The soundtrack, animations, gameplay, story, visual effects, behaviors, little details. It might be a bit slow, sure, but hell, I don't normally enjoy slow burners in movies or games, and yet, this game captured me after a couple of hours.Red Dead Redemption 2 is my favorite game, and if I could qualify it as a movie (Even though it isn't), I'd put it up there, competing with the best of the bests. There aren't enough adjectives for me to praise this amazing piece of media that everyone should, at least, try to experience.

author: Inkly
review: Gonna be honest, I only play(ed) the Online mode, I'm sure the single player is great but it's not my primary interest.Bought the game during the Steam sale, game is great but not full price great; get it on sale.Graphics: Very pretty, looks great love itRuns like garbage for your average system if your Rig isn't up to snuff, I run a RTX 2060 and it still barely gets to 35 FPS on max settings, you can drop them but it get muddy and ugly fast. Be ready for an unoptomized game; You've been warned.Grind: Compared to every MMO I've played and the grind hell that is GTA Online, this is a breath of fresh air. There are two currencies = Cash and Gold. Both can be obtained in fairly healthy amounts in-game. You CAN buy gold with IRL money though, but you don't have to at all. Gold is easily obtainable in-game and when bought with IRL money only speeds up progression instead of being a blocker from even being able to compete with others. A LOT of content automatically either makes you unkillable or instanced so harassment and endless murder during a mission is almost unheard of.Hackers: Unlike GTA Online, they are rare or at the very least, not as public about what they do. Because of the way the game plays, it's not exactly very fun for them to harass people. Not much of a reaction and that results in a ton of them either not being around or just not harassing people. I've run into a single hacker over the last 2 weeks i've been playing nonestop + multiple different timezones.Balance: So far so good, nearly every weapon is great; with a few rifles being borderline overpowered. It's still pretty fair and you don't feel like someone has bought a win against you. You can min-max some stuff so there are still the crazy guys that are harder to take down so try to be ready for them during a match.Focus: Instead of the power fantasy obsession of GTA Online, you get an incredibly solid western fantasy with all the horse riding and cowboy-Outlaw badassery included. If you don't enjoy long horse rides you won't enjoy this game. Tons of outfits, tons of PvE content to do, a large amount of it instanced as to not get harassed.Community: Miles better than the other platforms ESPECIALLY when compared to GTA Online. Folks naturally get into their roles and characters, due to the game's focus out of being a murder obsessed psychopath (GTAO) and into being your own character with a grey morality. There are still people that will kill you in the open world but they are a minority instead of the majority. You'll still get the odd ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ in the PvP modes but they're uncommon and easy to ignore.Most people you run into just say howdy or try to group up. Had a guy the other day tell me merry christmas, that's the kinda thing I love about this community.Be a little more trusting and you'll see that most folk are quite fun to interact with and a bit of a tussle didn't hurt no one. Don't take it personallyKids are rare (Due to the horse riding being boring for most of them) So that's great for us fellow adultsOverall a fantastic experience, I pissed off my significant other with how i've been obsessively playing this!9/10 needs more horse armor (I'm joking Rockstar please don't actually do this)

author: HeWhoDies
review: This game is phenomenal. I've ALWAYS been a Rockstar fan. Ever since the very first GTA game. I've played almost every Rockstar game, and this one so far takes the cake.The story is good. Voice acting is on point. Script is wonderful. The AI interactions are often hilarious, the environments are stunning and I could go on and on.Is it flawless? Hell no. It's a game, a program, it's bound to be flawed. But is it worth every dime? This gamer says yes.At the time of this review, it's 25% off. Buy it if you want it. You surely won't regret it if you're a Rockstar fan.

author: cebuninja
review: MICAH CAN GO ♥♥♥♥ HIMSELF AAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAAA

author: Setorrs The Lollygagger
review: Took me 60+ hours to finish it and here i am. I liked Red Dead Redemption 1 but good god i loved Red Dead Redemption 2. I was skeptical at first not getting to play my boy John Marston, but Arthur Morgan won me over really quick. Never have i seen such a well made character in a video game before. I really felt i was there with them through good and bad, like i was part of the gang. I felt every twist and turn of their path. I felt happy and sad, but I'm glad i put in the time to play this awesome story.The world is beautiful, it amazes me what some developers can do with the current tools at their disposal and other prefer to take the quick route and do a poor job. Not Rockstar, nope, they did an awesome job with the world, graphics are stunning, gun play made me feel like I was in a western even more than the first made me all those years ago when it came out.If you want to feel this game is right for you, if you want a western this game is right for you, if you want a beautiful world this game is right for you, if you want a really well rounded main character and cast this game is right for you. Just go buy it, enjoy the ride and thank me later.

author: Sooce
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 is one of the best single player games I've played in a long time.The Characters are amazing. The way they interacted with each other and the player was great, You feel connected to each character.The Story, Just being in a ragtag group of outlaws. going through the wild west together, going through hardships and victories. Gaining new people/ losing people. At a certain point in the game, every mission I did I was expecting to lose another person. The random events that happen around the world made the game feel so alive.The horses are great too. In other Rockstar games you go through multiple cars but in this game. I stuck with one horse the whole way through and got scared when it came close to dying. Never thought I would be attached to a virtual horse but ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ I was.I could go on and on about this game but that would take too long to type out. I HIGHLY recommend this game. It's so easy getting lost in it.

author: Eng.Adel23
review: Red Dead Redemption 2 ReviewThe reputation Rockstar has built over the last decade has fostered a level of expectation some may deem unfulfillable. Between GTA IV and V and the previous Red Dead, we’ve beheld iconic performances and tremendous leaps in animation, physics, and immersion. While you can sense the DNA of the acclaimed studio’s previous work in the follow-up to their Wild West hit, it’s nearly evolved past a point of recognition. I’ll come right out and say it: Red Dead Redemption 2 is a masterpiece that transcends the current generation and elevates gameplay and storytelling to a level of which is unprecedented. It exceeds far beyond my own expectations, and following more than seven years of passionate development, Rockstar has prevailed in crafting the finest game in their history and unequivocally the most immersive open world ever created.The story occurs in 1899, more than a decade before the events of John Marston’s tale in the first game. As the 19th century draws to a conclusion, so too does the era of outlaws in the American West. You fill the boots of Arthur Morgan, a senior member and lead enforcer in the infamous Van der Linde gang. Following a job gone haywire in the town of Blackwater, the gang heads north to escape the federal agents and bounty hunters who are hot on their heels.You quickly grasp a sense of the inevitable doom that awaits the gang’s lifestyle. The civilized world is rapidly evolving, and their ways of living within it are shifting to survival tactics as they rob and fight across the American frontier. Throughout the story, the gang relocates to diverse areas as they flee law and order. While they intend to steal enough cash to escape the clutches of justice once and for all, they struggle to make ends meet as divisions rise.Expertly paced and masterfully written, the tale of the Van der Linde gang is one that will forever remain with me. The game takes you on an emotional roller coaster as you get to know Arthur and his fellow gang members throughout sixty plus hours of the main story. Themes of loyalty, betrayal, revolution, and the American Dream are woven deep into a truly captivating, funny, and at times heartbreaking narrative. I loved every moment I spent with the engaging and diverse cast as the story unfolded, and I desperately wish I could experience it all over again for the first time. What’s more is the prevalence of player choice, and the world reacts to your day to day decisions as Arthur Morgan.

review: A significant number of players cannot play the game due to a variety of errors like the infamous ERR_GFX_STATE, which in some cases like in mine prevents the game fron launching at all.The answers from rockstar support as well as various "fixes" found online do not seem to improve the situation and sadly the new updates seem unable to fix the problem.I'm running Win7 on quite a strong maching but sadly the game is completly unplayable.Will change the review if the crashes on launch even get fixed, that is if I have not refunded the game by then.

author: VenomSS
review: Over 130hrs played, this review will be based predominantly on the Online portion of the game. Far, far too many hackers. They are unbridled currently. They will spawn you into locked rooms, kill you repeatedly with a kill command, drain your bank accounts, teleport, run around in god mode, aim bot, pick you up and drop you from high altitude and just generally ruin the entire experience. Pretty much guarantee your game will be ruined by a hacker at least once every 2 hours. Maybe more. This will require you to quit the game and start another...which you will find is a common theme.Then there are the bugs / glitches. The VERY first thing you do in the game is glitched. It asks you to name your horse, and freezes there. A restart is required. Pretty much sets the tone for the rest of the experience though. Long load screens that load into black screens or never load at all. Poor animal spawn rates..where most everything in the game revolves around animal spawns. Not getting credit for daily challenges you clearly completed, while everyone else in your party gets credit. Your horse will sometimes just stand still, cant be moved. Many things require you quit the game and restart completely to resolve. This is just scratching the surface...but the running theme seems to be restart the game every few hours or less and watch long loading screens. Cross your fingers it actually loads.On the positive side, when everything works as intended the game is beautiful and fun. But the hackers and glitches REALLY hobble the experience.*update* LOGGED IN 2 YEARS LATER AFTER UNINSTALLING, VERY FIRST GAME WITHIN 5 MINS encountered 2 hackers using god mode, spawning in tornadoes, etc. Relogged to a different lobby, connection kept dropping every 5 mins. Online is still an unplayable dumpster fire.

author: NickyJ
review: Several hundred hours later into the game, I have two different ratings for the game:Singleplayer: 10/10. The story is superb. It's linear enough to truly be a story, but with an open world that lets you choose when you want to move on with the story. The moral system gives you a fair amount of influence over how you look at the story and the main character. The open world ranges from beautiful snowy mountain peaks to swamps and deserts. Many interesting jobs and people are found in those lands, all of them unique but not so outlandish to be annoying (looking at you, GTA).Multiplayer: 5/10. The open world has lots to do, but 80% of it is locked behind a pay-or-grind wall covered with suggestions to pay. Each set of skills you can use (bounty hunting, trading, moon shining, etc.) is unlocked through gold bars that you can spend a week or two grinding for, or you can TOTALLY JU$T $HELL OUT $OME MONEY, JU$T CLICK HERE FOR YOUR PA$$. They're cool once you get them, but it gets boring fast if you don't have a solid group of friends to form a posse and play with. Server stability is also lacking. Not as horrid as it once was, but the game has inconvenient moments of crashing after taking your ingame money but before giving you possession of what you bought. Too bad lol, guess you'll have to buy that train ticket again.Oh yeah, the singleplayer story is about working for a gang of thieves who rob banks and trains, right? Well you can't do that online. But you can buy the content where some nature hippie gets mad at you for killing animals when you hunt for your traders business. Priorities.

author: Doggsen
review: Truly one of the best games i've ever played and i have played  it a lot. I'm a huge fan of immersion in games and this game has really set new standards for me. The story itself is fantastic but it was the rich open world as well that tied me up in front of my PC. You play as Arthur Morgan in the year 1899 who is a gangmember of John Marston's old gang and get to see what happened before the events of Red Dead Redemption 1. Every gangmember has his or her own unique background story making them distinctive. Ruthless gunslingers or sweet and innocent looking young women who take advantage of their skills as thieves. You really get to either love or hate them. The story missions offer much variety. Next to the obvious robberies and heists there are also few fun missions that made me smirk but i don't want to spoiler here. Just a small hint  The open-world felt vivid. NPCs weren't simply just chunks of meat standing around but felt like real people. Every simple action has consequences, from simply robbing a shop owner to robbing a whole bank.Red Dead Redemption 2 has its own crime & bounty system. You get to choose as what type of person you're playing as. Be a ruthless outlaw or a kind and merciful feller. Be a good guy and gain advantages like reduced prices at shops. Be an outlaw and have bountyhunters hunting you. As a gangmember you constantly have to keep your other gangmembers in mind. You're basically responsible for everything. You have to hunt for food or pay the ammo for example.In addition to that RDR2 even offers an immersive hair-system as well a weight-gain system. While the hair-system does not actively change your experience, the weight-gain system does. Eat too much and lose stamina, don't eat at all and lose health.There are a lots of activities and minigames that keep you occupied like poker, tabletop games, fishing etc. Furthermore, there exist numerous random events just like in the previous RDR. However, they're optional but they will increase your good honor stats once you help (The crime and bounty system i mentioned earlier). The event vary from helping a captured citizen who is held at gunpoint by outlaws to rather hilarious saloon brawls. Did i mention you even have friendship system with your horse?Graphicwise it really does manage to keep up with current standards. From forests to swamps to snowy mountains, villages, huge cities, canyons; This game just looks pretty yet it is demanding and i strongly recommend watching an optimization guide to get the most enjoyable experience possible.  It does not feel dull and every region has its own charm. There's a fast-traveling system in RDR2 but i rather rode to my destination!The gun system is pretty decent. There's a fair amount of guns you can choose from. Revolvers, pistols, shotguns, repeaters, rifles and more. Every single one feels like they should. The hit-feedback is amazing. I quite enjoyed the fact that bullets actually caused bulletholes in bodies depending on where you hit them and not just plain blood effects.What about the soundtrack? Breathtaking. While being scripted most of the times (there are no radios on horses duh) it gave the gunfights that certain "something".  The soundtrack made me wanna be a gunslinger wandering around on a horse. Not even exaggerating at this point. My personal favourite is "American Venom". Soundtracks that are not performed during combat are mostly harmonica ones.. since RDR2 takes place in the late 19th century. Okay, after praising the game i want to tell you something i did not like. The controls felt rather clunky in certain situations. I know Arthur is not a trained elite fighter. Instead of doing a roll he just throws himself into the ground when jumping to the side while aiming a weapon. Also, looking for cover can be fiddly since Arthur just goes to the nearest cover possible. By the way i played with a controller so i don't know what it's like with mouse and keyboard. Probably worse.Sometimes the horse does what it  wants and struggles to jump over the simplest obstacles or even worse; tripping over small rocks. While first being rather funny it got annoying.While reading other reviews you might have noticed how bad the online mode is. Does it really deserve the hate? I think it does partially.  While the PvE modes offer a wide variety of missions like heists, bounty hunting or robberies, the PvP experience is where it starts to stink. There is no shortage of coward cheaters in this game who will kill you for no reason. Does not matter if it's in free roam, during a mission or the shootout modes. They'll use godmodes, aimbots or invisibility cheats  to ruin your day. I encounter a cheater every fifth or sixth match. Apart from that the online mode is pure grinding. As a newbie you don't stand the slightest chance against other players in PvP. They have more HP, more stamina, better equipment and the worst of all far better dead eye abilities that are just unfair. Even if you want to change your clothing you must grind for several hours. A cool looking coat  or a somewhat decent gun cost around 250$ ingame dollars. A mission (approx. 15 minutes) usually rewards you with around 10-30$. You do the math. I'm not saying the online mode is not fun at all. I enjoy hanging out with fellow gunslingers and doing shenanigans but speaking of PvP... i recommend sticking to PvE (especially as a new player). I wish Rockstar Games would make more effort banning the cheaters.The single player is one of the best experiences i have had in video games. The story,  visuals,  cinematics, soundtrack,  gameplay has set up new standards for every upcoming triple A title.This Rockstar Game's open world   is a game you'll lose yourself in for 50-100 hours if not longer. You don't even have to like the western setting to appreciate the love and effort they put in this marvelous game. Regarding Red Dead Online; if you stick to PvE and have no problems with grinding it is fine. You will encounter good & bad people just like in any other game.9,5/10
